My apologies for the long silence! I've had a jam-packed weekend so far. My teachers seem determined to test my knowledge, as I discovered I have around 20 tests on Tuesday! But, on a brighter note, we had marching band practice yesterday. It was a cool experience as we stayed indoors the entire time, and I got to play second part, making the musical portion rather straightforward.

I left marching at around 5:00 PM and then met up with my friends for dinner, a plan made before I knew about the extra marching practice. It was a fun celebration as it was Kelly's birthday! Afterwards, we headed to Kel's house for a sleepover, filled with exciting activities. Despite the sleepover, I surprisingly went to bed earlier than usual because I had to attend a Bar Mitzvah this morning. It was a pretty interesting event.

For my CR project, we need to visit two places of worship different from our own. Naturally, one will be a Jewish synagogue, and I'm leaning towards a mosque for my other visit, although my plans might change. This has been my only opportunity to write, but I must go now. Maybe I'll have time to write more later. 

Until next time, *Ya di amore!*"



Let me know if you need anything else!

rewrite_original:
It's later now, and my parents have found a "constructive" activity for me: cleaning. Grrr, why do they always resort to chores? It's so annoying! I was enjoying a peaceful moment, free from homework, listening to jazz, when suddenly, "Hey Catie, go clean!"  My usual response, "Yeah, sure, fine, I'll clean," escaped my lips. (Spoiler alert: I almost never actually do it.)

But this time, my mom came upstairs, her voice dripping with that guilt-inducing "momly" tone, and asked me nicely to clean.  So, I reluctantly trudged downstairs, gathered the necessary cleaning supplies, and tackled the bathroom. Bleh! Cleaning is my nemesis. 

Suddenly, a crazy plan popped into my head. I should become a gold digger, marry a wealthy guy, and hire a cleaning lady and a cook to make me peanut butter sandwiches all day long.  Then, when I become super fat and he wants a divorce, I'll be golden – no prenuptial agreement means I'll get half his assets!

Of course, I'd need to become a witch first to make any guy, let alone a rich one, marry me. But now that I've shared my plan, I'll have to come up with a new one. Oh well.

Truth be told, I have nothing much to write about, but I'm not in the mood to chat with anyone.  I wish I could go to the park, my favorite place in the world. I'd bring my mini disc player, swing on the swings, and let my thoughts drift. It's a fantastic place to be alone and contemplate things – except when those little kids come along and stare at me like I'm Frankenstein because I'm a "big kid" on a swing. They get terrified and avoid the other swing, which drives them crazy because I usually stay there for an hour or so.  I adore little kids; they make me laugh. :)

Well, I've probably bored you enough. I'll write more later. ~Ya di amore~

The afternoon sun had already dipped lower in the sky when my parents assigned me a chore - cleaning. Always the champions of "constructive" activities, they seemed to think tidying up was the answer to all my woes. I was lost in a world of peaceful jazz and homework-free bliss when I was summoned to the realm of domestic drudgery.

Reluctantly, I agreed, though I rarely followed through on such promises. My mother's gentle persuasion, however, worked its magic, leaving me feeling a twinge of guilt. So, I trudged downstairs, gathered the necessary cleaning supplies, and braced myself for the battle against the bathroom.

Cleaning held no appeal for me whatsoever. My mind wandered to a fantastical scenario: being a gold digger, snagging a wealthy husband who could afford a personal cleaning lady and a chef dedicated to whipping up peanut butter sandwiches. I'd live a carefree life until the inevitable weight gain and divorce, hopefully with a good settlement thanks to a lack of a prenuptial agreement. To achieve this dream, I'd need to work on my charm, a skill I hadn't quite mastered. 

This newfound clarity about my "destiny" meant I needed a new plan.  While I wasn't particularly social and found myself  lacking inspiration, I found solace in writing. A yearning for the park, my sanctuary, grew within me. I envisioned myself there, swinging on the swings, my mini disc player blasting music, lost in contemplation.

The park was a place of peace, a haven for solitude,  except for the occasional curious children who would stare, puzzled, at the sight of an older kid swinging alone.  It was heartwarming, though, how their presence could bring a spark of joy and laughter. 

I apologize for the rambling. Perhaps I'll share more thoughts another time.

~Ya di amore~

The day had grown late when my parents assigned me a chore they deemed "constructive" - cleaning. It was frustrating, as usual, how they always came up with these tasks. I was relishing some downtime, enjoying the music and freedom from homework, when they interrupted my peace. Reluctantly, I agreed, though I rarely followed through. But my mother's gentle persistence made me feel guilty, so I begrudgingly descended to the bathroom armed with cleaning supplies.

Cleaning isn't my forte. While scrubbing, I daydreamed about a fantastical life: marrying a wealthy man who could afford a cleaning lady and a personal chef to make peanut butter sandwiches for me. I envisioned a carefree existence until, inevitably, I gained weight and the marriage ended in divorce. Perhaps I'd walk away with a healthy share of the assets, thanks to a lack of a prenuptial agreement.  This daydream, of course, required me to become more charming, a feat I wasn't sure I could accomplish. 

With my newfound "plan" exposed, I realized I needed a new strategy. Despite lacking the desire to socialize, I found solace in writing.  

My mind wandered to the park, my sanctuary. I imagined myself there, swinging on the swings, listening to music on my mini disc player, lost in thought. The decision not to go weighed on me, but a conversation with Chris was incredibly helpful. He's a fantastic listener and truly cares. Initially hesitant to share my feelings, Chris encouraged me to open up, which I'm grateful for. Releasing those emotions was cathartic. Tears flowed freely - the first time in ages, perhaps since my grandmother's funeral. Her absence still deeply hurts. I realize I need to allow myself to feel these emotions more often, as bottling them up intensifies the pain.

A longing for genuine connection surfaced. I yearn to be liked for who I am, to feel valued. Uncertainty about myself plagues me. While I may not be conventionally attractive, I strive to be a good person. I struggle to comprehend why I haven't found the acceptance I seek.  

The effort I put forth often feels unappreciated. It's disheartening. However, I find solace in writing and confiding in trusted individuals like Chris. This space allows me to process my thoughts and emotions, knowing it's unlikely to be scrutinized.  

With a sense of relief, I bid farewell to this day and turn towards a restful night.



After much deliberation, I decided against going. Instead, I reached out to Chris, confiding in him about everything that had been weighing on my mind. It was incredibly therapeutic.  Chris is truly one of the most supportive people I know; he's always there to listen without judgment, especially when I'm feeling down. Initially, I hesitated to share my feelings, but he gently encouraged me to open up, and I'm so grateful that I did.  

Expressing my pain allowed me to finally shed tears, a release I hadn't experienced in a long time, perhaps since my grandmother's funeral. Her absence continues to deeply wound me. I've realized that I need to embrace my emotions more fully, as suppressing them only intensifies the pain when it eventually surfaces.

On a deeper level, I yearn for genuine connection and acceptance. I crave someone who appreciates me for who I truly am.  I struggle to understand why I find it so difficult to connect with others.  While I may not be conventionally attractive, I strive to be a kind and decent person, yet I often feel unappreciated.

Despite my efforts, I feel like I'm constantly putting myself out there without receiving adequate recognition. It's disheartening, to say the least. 

However, I find solace in writing and confiding in trusted individuals like Chris. It helps me process my emotions and gain clarity.  

For now, I'll prioritize self-care and hope for brighter days ahead. Goodnight.

We watched the senior movie last week, featuring the song "We Go On," which was from my freshman year show. It always brings back a wave of sadness.

Then, last night, I had the most unsettling conversation with Chris. He blurted out, "What if I just told you how I really feel about you?"  I was completely thrown off, unsure if he was serious or not.  I couldn't hear his voice clearly, making it even more confusing. I panicked, thinking about how to respond delicately, considering he'd already had a rough week. Later that night, someone asked why I didn't date Chris. It seems people don't understand that we're just close friends, nothing more. I couldn't imagine dating Chris – it would be too awkward and strange.  

I know it might sound harsh, but I just don't feel that way about him. He feels the same, so I wish people would just accept that. Chris and I are strictly friends, and that's all we'll ever be. I'm tired of the speculation and assumptions. 

I wish people would realize that having guy friends doesn't automatically mean I'm romantically interested in them.  I had a conversation with Bryan about this, and he gets it. Bryan is a great friend to talk to, and I'm glad he's in my life.  To be clear, I don't have romantic feelings for Bryan either. 

I hope this clarifies things.

While I admit that some attention can be nice, the hurt it causes outweighs it.  People make fun of my vision problems, and it's infuriating. It's easy for them to mock, but they wouldn't dare try to fix it.  I know I have difficulty seeing; it's not a choice.  I wish people would just back off. They might temporarily stop, but they always return to their hurtful behavior.

I can't help but wonder why I'm such an easy target. What makes me so vulnerable to their ridicule? I try to be a decent person, kind, honest, and moral, but all I get is negativity. It makes me question the point of trying to be good when it's met with constant rejection.  

It pains me to see how society glorifies negative behavior.  Being drunk on Friday night, having multiple sexual partners, and being mean-spirited are all considered "cool."  It's disheartening to see genuine kindness and integrity disregarded.

I'm exhausted by it all. I struggle to find respect for anyone at my school.  I yearn for summer to arrive, for a brief escape from this misery. But then the cycle starts again the following year:  disillusionment, frustration, and disappointment.

My desire is to stay in Michigan, to distance myself from this environment. I want to be surrounded by people I don't know, people who haven't had the chance to hurt me yet.  Maybe there, I can find a glimmer of hope, a chance to believe in the possibility of good.


Why subject myself to four more years of this? Four years of self-loathing disguised as acceptance? Four years of wasting time on people I'll likely never see again? It's a bleak thought.

The ache of Victoria's absence is a constant companion. I miss the way she'd answer my call, her presence a comforting balm. Every need I had, she fulfilled with unwavering devotion.  The nightly ritual of her sleeping beside me, a source of warmth and security, is now a hollow memory.  

I miss the exclusivity of our bond, the undeniable knowledge that she cherished only me.  The familiar refrain, "Catie, go get Victoria, you're the only one who can," echoes in my ears, a reminder of the unique connection we shared.

Her uncanny ability to sense my sadness, no matter where I was in the house, and her instinctive need to comfort me was a gift beyond measure.  

She was truly mine, a soul that loved me unconditionally, accepting me for every facet of my being. She didn't seek to change me, to mold me into something different. Her love was a reflection of my authentic self.

The image of finding her lifeless on the floor remains a searing wound, a brutal reminder of the fragility of life and the depth of my loss.  

I grieve the comfort she offered, the silent companionship, the shared moments of joy and sorrow. She would have been beside me now, a furry presence offering solace, a willing listener to my tears.

The pain is overwhelming, a resurgence of grief that threatens to consume me.  Crying, I know, won't bring her back. Yet, the need to express this profound sorrow is a force I cannot resist.  

She was the one who loved me without reservation, a devotion so pure and unwavering.  It feels as if a shard of glass has pierced my heart, leaving a gaping wound that may never fully heal.

The day the seniors left hung heavy with a melancholic air. While I didn't personally know any of them, their departure served as a stark reminder of my own impending senior year and the inevitable goodbye that awaited me. 

The thought of leaving my friends, of not seeing them on a daily basis, filled me with a profound sadness.  Next year would bring another wave of goodbyes as my best friend and several other close friends embarked on their separate paths. Though I was fortunate to have other incredible friends in my senior year, the thought of those departures still weighed heavily on my mind.

Chris, my confidante, was the one who caused me the most worry. Our easygoing conversations and comfortable silences were something I cherished deeply. The prospect of losing that connection after he went to college terrified me. I feared that distance and time would erode our bond, leaving me with only memories.

This fear stemmed from a deep-seated dread of forming close attachments, knowing that they inevitably change or dissolve.  Past experiences with Christy, Amanda, and even Kelly (though our friendship felt different, irreplaceable) served as painful reminders of this truth. 

Kelly, with her unwavering presence in my life, was the one constant I knew I could rely on.  Our long-standing bond gave me unwavering faith that we would remain connected, no matter the distance.  

My other close friends, however, felt less certain. Kelly C., with her aspirations of becoming a famous clarinet player, seemed destined for a path vastly different from mine. Kathryn, while I hoped we'd stay in touch, I sensed a growing distance in our future. Emily, with her potential move to Europe, posed a significant challenge to maintaining our connection.  Joanne, already leaving for England, added another layer of uncertainty to the tapestry of my friendships.

Overwhelmed with these thoughts, I realized I needed to curb my anxieties.  I hadn't even considered the implications for my guy friends. The sheer volume of potential goodbyes threatened to consume me. 

Despite the overwhelming sadness, I reminded myself of the blessings in my life. Change, however, was a struggle for me to accept.

I longed for the comfort of belonging, for a place where I could be vulnerable and express my emotions without fear.  But the reality of change and goodbyes loomed large, casting a shadow over my otherwise joyful life.  



The day the seniors left school hit me harder than expected. Even though I didn't know them well, seeing them go made me realize how close I am to facing the same goodbye. The thought of leaving my friends, of not seeing them every day, filled me with sadness. 

Next year will be especially tough because not only will my best friend be gone, but other close friends will be heading off to different paths as well.  While I'll still have amazing friends in my senior year, the thought of saying goodbye weighs heavily on me.

Chris, in particular, worries me. We have a unique connection; I can talk to him easily, and spending time alone with him feels natural and comfortable. I fear that after college, our connection will fade, and we'll lose touch.

This fear stems from a painful truth: best friends often leave. Whether it's distance, changing paths, or simply growing apart, it's a recurring pattern. I've experienced it with Christy and Amanda, and while Kelly will always be my friend, no matter what, I can't help but feel apprehensive about the future with others. 

I barely talk to Christy anymore, and my connection with Amanda is largely due to our mothers' friendship.  I still care deeply for them, but the closeness has faded. Kelly C. and I seem destined for different paths, and while I'll celebrate her success as a clarinet player, I doubt we'll stay in close contact. Kathryn and I might try to keep in touch, but life often gets in the way.

Emily's potential move to Europe leaves me with a knot of worry. Maintaining long-distance friendships is difficult. Joanne's move to England adds another layer of uncertainty. Simply thinking about all these goodbyes is overwhelming. I haven't even considered my guy friends, but the thought alone is too much to bear.

It's frustrating because I've been so fortunate in life.  But change is hard for me to accept.  I crave the security of constant connection, and the thought of losing those bonds fills me with sadness.

I tried connecting with someone online, but realized I'm not capable of a meaningful conversation right now. Even attempting one feels foolish. I'd probably say something I don't mean or something hurtful. I feel terrible, lonely, and low. I know I have amazing friends, but I just feel isolated at the moment. I guess it's normal to feel lonely sometimes.  

Ironically, even though I feel lonely, I also crave solitude. I don't want to interact with most people at school tomorrow. Maybe a few close friends, like my lunch group, but that's it. I just want to be left alone – no conversations, no distractions, no teasing.

I desperately miss Amanda. Moving to Texas was a huge loss. And Heather, if she's changed for the better, I want to spend a lot of time with her this summer. 

Is today over yet? Is tomorrow even over?  I'm failing at my own quote, "never let the sunset on tomorrow before the sun rises today."

I had a strange dream the other night, involving someone very close to me. It was confusing – I'm still trying to decipher its meaning.

All I want is to finish this speech and then curl up with a book and sleep. What's wrong with me?**

With a piercing shriek of frustration, "AHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHH!!!!", the speaker poured out their overwhelming stress. Every word dripped with exhaustion: "So stressed right now. So so so very stressed." Their annoyance towards a particular individual was palpable, repeated with a fervent intensity that spoke volumes about the depth of their frustration. "So sick of him. So sick of him."

The speaker believed this person deliberately sought to provoke them, describing a daily torment as if orchestrated: "He does everything he possibly can to annoy me. It's like he tries to. It's like he wakes up in the morning and thinks of ways to make me mad."  

The weight of the situation was so heavy that even the thought of connecting with others felt impossible. "I just went online and realized that there's no way I can have a conversation with anyone right now. It's stupid to even consider trying, it really is." The fear of saying something out of anger only amplified their despair, leading to a feeling of being deeply low and terrible: "I'm just going to say something I don't mean or something. Argh. I feel so low and terrible and...lonely."

Despite acknowledging the support of their "awesome friends", the speaker felt a profound sense of isolation. "I know I have awesome friends, but I guess I just feel lonely right now. I guess it's normal. Everyone's allowed to feel lonely." This contradiction of wanting connection yet craving solitude was evident: "Heh, I feel lonely, yet at the same time, I want to be left alone."

School presented an unwelcome prospect, a place where the speaker longed for anonymity: "I don't want to see anyone at school tomorrow. Maybe a few people, but not most. I want people to just leave me alone at school tomorrow. Not talk to me, not nag me, poke me, tease me. None of that." Their only solace was the imagined company of a select few, their "lunch gang".

Longing for lost connections, they yearned for the company of Amanda and Heather: "I wish I could see Amanda. Man, I miss her so much. I wish she hadn't moved to Texas. :( I wish I could see Heather too. If she's changed some of her ways, I want to see her a lot this summer." 

The relentless passage of time felt unbearable, a constant reminder of their current predicament. "Argh. Is today over yet? Is tomorrow over yet? Heh, I'm not exactly following my quote, 'never let the sunset on tomorrow before the sun rises today.' "

The only solace in sight was a brief respite from the turmoil: "Who knows? I just need to do this speech crap so that I can go read and sleep."

I'm  already anxious about tomorrow. We were supposed to spend the whole day at Great America, but I backed out because  I knew a lot of people would be there.  Instead, Ryan suggested something else, like bowling or a movie, but I'm having second thoughts.

The truth is, I'm afraid that seeing him will make me start liking him again.  And I really don't want that. Our relationship didn't work out before, and I know it would hurt both of us if we tried again.  It took us a while to get back to being friends after the breakup.

On the other hand, I feel bad for not wanting to see him.  Maybe I'm not being a good friend. I have a feeling that if I go out with him, we'll end up back together. And honestly,  part of me wants that, because I just want to be in a relationship.

Tonight was fun. I went to Peter's party, which was pretty good. I didn't know anyone there except Kelly and Annie, which was a little disappointing. Chris and Brandon went off to play video games, but I ended up hanging out with Chris later on, which was nice.

I guess I'm just really worried about what's going to happen tomorrow. I feel like I wasn't fully present when I was talking to Chris, and that makes me feel bad.

  I guess I'll just have to wait and see what happens.

The day started off amazing! After sleeping in thanks to my lunch final, I went to my government final, which I miraculously aced with a 97%.  

With my confidence soaring, I met up with Kelly, Joanne, John, Kathryn, and Mary Clare for lunch.  We ended up at Einsteins after two other restaurants were too crowded. I was craving a peanut butter and jelly bagel, but decided to save it for when I was with Diane. 

Lately, I've been feeling like Diane doesn't like me much. I wonder if I've done something to upset her or if she doesn't trust me. I feel like I should apologize, but I'm not sure what for. I really want to be closer friends with her, but I'm not sure if she feels the same.

After lunch, we went paddle boating, which was a blast even though it was a bit chilly.  Switching places in the backseat with four people in the boat wasn't the best idea though!  We then stopped at Starbucks, where I opted for a fruit drink instead of coffee.

Kathryn's mom picked us up and took us to Joanne's house. We hung out, did karaoke, and played spoons...with forks!  Yikes, I accidentally cut myself, but Joanne saved the day with an Elmo bandaid. 

I think we might have accidentally upset Kathryn, but she was too nice to show it.

Tonight, I'm going to Peter's party.  Although I wasn't sure if I wanted to go at first, so many people are going that I decided to give it a shot. Chris is picking me up in about an hour.

Tomorrow looks promising too! I'm planning to spend the whole day with Ryan. We decided against going to Great America since it's crowded with people I know.

Well, that's all for now. Time for some fun, school-free activities! WOOOOOOOOOOHOOOOOOOOOO!!!"

I was craving a peanut butter and jelly bagel but decided to save it for my next outing with Diane. Lately, I've been feeling a little insecure about our friendship. I sometimes feel like she doesn't like me much or trusts me, so I'm thinking about apologizing even though I don't know what I did wrong. 

After lunch, we went paddle boating, which was a blast! It was a little chilly, but the fun definitely made up for it. We had a few hilarious mishaps, like trying to switch places in the backseat with four people in the boat – not recommended! 

We stopped by Starbucks for a refreshing fruit drink for me (coffee isn't really my thing).  Kathryn's mom picked us up and drove us to Joanne's, where we spent the afternoon singing karaoke and playing spoons (with forks, which was a bit dangerous – I even cut myself!). There's a sense of regret and missed opportunities. The speaker urges the other person to seize the day, never letting the "sun set on tomorrow before the sun rises today."

Despite knowing the importance of a regular sleep schedule, I don't think I'll be able to stick to it while I'm in Michigan. So, a 9 o'clock bedtime seems unrealistic. I've been feeling a bit out of sorts lately, even acting strangely—like the time my ponytail holder flew across the room!

There isn't much else to report for now, though I have come across some potentially useful information.  I'm planning to wait until college to make any concrete decisions. I'm really excited about college and the opportunity to meet more mature people.

I'm also happy for Joanne and her partner, hoping their relationship will stay strong despite the year-long separation ahead. They seem to have a solid bond and the qualities needed to overcome challenges.

Anyway, I'm going to make that grilled cheese and relax with a book. Oh, and I seem to have forgotten to sign this note regularly—hopefully, it won't be a big deal!

My bad mood had clouded my judgment, but that was no excuse for my behavior.  I'd even asked her to Great America this summer, a testament to the genuine connection I felt.

Now, guilt gnawed at me. "I'm sorry, Diane," I whispered, the words catching in my throat. "I'm truly sorry. It wasn't you, it was my mood, and I'm so sorry I took it out on you."  This was what I would say, hoping she'd understand.  I knew she understood the depths of despair a bad few days could bring. I just hoped she could forgive me.
